content.description: Awesome overhang to thin slab problem. Going direct makes this thing a solid V4, while veering either left or right makes for some easier/interesting variations.
content.protection: A pad or two and some spotters.
content.location: The obvious overhang feature that greets you upon entering the west side of the corridor.

content.description:
Hands to offwidth problem just left of Will's Problem.

Start under the overhang with some semi-decent hand jams. Pull out of the roof and into the offwidth with some grunty technique. Fun.

A funky, fun and short little problem starting in a flaring pod at the bottom of a crack.

Lean into the pod/crack with your feet smearing out left to start. Sidepull and traverse into the next verticle crack, get your feet and pull up and left one more time for the easy top out. Probably no more than 5 moves in total, but really fun warm up candidate.
content.location: At the same distance from the river as "Knee Stacker" but closer to the boat ramp. This one is easy to miss because it's not tall, so just take a look at the picture and wander the river bank until you find it.

content.description:
A fun and balance-y problem with a challenging move well above the deck.

Sit start on a low rail on the bulge to the left (Will's Problem). Get into the finger crack and then move up and right onto the face, pulling through worsening crimps on worsening feet until you can high step or mantel up. From here, find good holds to top out on.

The sit-start doesn't add to the grade or the fun, but does add two semi-physical moves if you are looking to maximize fitness.
content.location: Located in the the Corridor area. If you are walking down the corridor with the boat ramp behind you, this is the last problem on your left. It starts on the right side of the overhanging bulge. Check the photo on this problem and Will's Problem for good visual beta.

content.description:
Woooo! This thing is a BEAST.  Start as deep in the cave as possible, and just start shuffling along.

Awkward toe-heel camming arm stretching shoulder popping hand/finger locking desperation. Top out to the left of the cave.

Required a good deck brushing to remove the dust and grime upon my last visit, but with a little commitment this thing could totally go.

I've gotten close, but I can't quite connect the moves. It feels like it's at LEAST a V7, but feels similar to V9-V10's I've been on.

Will someone please do this!?!?
content.protection: About 3-4 pads and a spotter at the end would be sufficient.
content.location:
On the opposite of the boulder that makes up the north wall of the corridor, only accessible/dry when water is at its lowest.  November is the best time.

(note: Last time we visited, someone had built a fire ring directly under this.  We spent a half hour moving all the rocks and wood. If you come up on something similar, please also take the time to preserve the rock here. fire = death to boulders)

content.description: Interesting problem, very fun. Stack that knee and catch the crimp!
content.protection: A pad or two and some spotters.
content.location: To the north west of the corridor. Look for the shelf.

content.description:
An interesting and sustained traverse. The line meanders between solid lips to thin edges to slopey desperation.  For full value, start far to the right, and top out far to the left (highball). Or stick to the center section of the traverse to keep it safer and bring it down a grade or two.

There are two distinct cruxes. The thin section in the middle of the traverse, and the other is the committing top out.  The top out is over or under water for the vast majority of the year.
content.protection: 3-4 pads with a few spotters to leap frog them as you go. Stacked pads and good spotters for the top out are mandatory.
content.location: Traverses the shelf from right to left on the boulder that makes up the north wall of the corridor, and tops out high.
